Award.AwardTitle: DCL NSF INCLUDES Workshop: High-Leverage Problems, Useful Data, Formative Evaluation, Effective Communication
Award.AbstractNarration:
SRI International and the Carnegie Foundation for Advancement of Teaching will jointly lead a workshop with the dual goals of supporting INCLUDES ((Inclusion across the Nation of Communities of Learners that have been Underrepresented for Diversity in Engineering and Science) Launch Pilots during their first year and contributing to plans for a National Backbone. The workshop will strengthen and deepen the potential for rapid, continuous improvement cycles within and across INCLUDES networks. To do so, they will combine the expertise of SRI and Carnegie in improvement science, rapid analytics, and fostering networks of researchers and practitioners to engage participants in conducting a complete improvement cycle within and across INCLUDES Launch Pilots.

The workshop will have three phases. A first phase, conducted online, will share expertise related to each of the four parts of a complete improvement cycle: (1) problem definition, (2) data collection, (3) formative evaluation, and (4) effective communication. This first phase will combine an initial presentation with facilitated, online opportunities to interactively engage in the topics. A second phase, conducted face-to-face, will work intensively with teams from INCLUDES networks to improve their operational and long-term plans. The third phase will reflect and report on the workshop and contribute plans to build capacities for the National Backbone organization. Through the combination of these three phases, they will support the first-year work of INCLUDES teams and also refine understanding of how a national network could combine online and face-to-face elements to advance INCLUDES efforts. The workshop team will create and disseminate resources that are immediately useful to INCLUDES and related projects, and the workshop will openly coordinate with other workshops to achieve synergies. The online offerings will be open, broadly advertised, and permanently available. The lessons learned regarding plans for a national backbone will be disseminated broadly. In addition to participants from INCLUDES networks, additional stakeholders will be invited to both phases so as to shape the future plans to achieve broader impacts aligned with overall INCLUDES goals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to familiarize NSF INCLUDES Design and Development Launch Pilots (DDLPs) from Cohort 1 of the NSF INCLUDES grant program with the concept of Networked Improvement Communities (NICs). Through a series of webinars and one two-day in person meeting, participants were to be offered the opportunity to learn about NICs, when they are appropriate, the chartering process, methods associated with organizing and sustain them and how to evaluate them. We presented four essential and coherently related anchors for such sharing: (1) high leverage problems, (2) using data to improve, (3) formative evaluation, and (4) communication within and across networks. 

The NSF INCLUDES Center website https://includescenter.org was designed to support the Networked Improvement Community workshop project. It has a description of the work SRI completed under this award. Descriptions of the project team and their areas of expertise were provided, and a form to complete to contact the team was also furnished on the site. An introductory webinar provides an overview to what a networked improvement community is, under what circumstances a group of organizations or institutions may want to establish a network , and what can be expected when participating in a network. Each of the four critical components of NIC development have their own webpage that provide a link to the recorded webinar, which is also publicly available on the internet via SRI’s YouTube channel (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCe67CJpaBgMtpAzkpDExwvQ/feed).

In addition to these five webinars, SRI International hosted a face-to-face workshop for NSF INCLUDES DDLPs from the first cohort at SRI's headquarters in Menlo Park, CA. The workshop was attended by 20 NSF INCLUDES DDLP grantees representing 8 different projects that had demonstrated interest in developing a networked improvement community within their area of research. The lessons learned in this workshop were applied across these 8 projects in the development and evolution of their burgeoning networks. Of the 8 project participants, four became part of a cohort of five follow-on grants (NSF INCLUDES Alliance awards). The workshop gave grantees the opportunity to not only learn about networked improvement communities, but network among themselves and create strong partnerships that resulted in the formation of strong alliances and partnerships for future work.

Networked Improvement Communities (NICs) are a catalyst for change at a broad level. Community organizations, laboratories, and governments utilize the NIC model for community mobilization that incorporates various entities such as hospitals, universities, and social services. The wide applicability of NICs in both scientific communities and the public sphere make the work and resources developed under this grant applicable on to a wide audience.
